A light hearted wonderful game with a great sense of humour.

McPixel is a fast paced indie game that stars “McPixel” a strange character that goes around saving the day from all things explosive!
You are thrown into various different situations in various different settings and given 20 seconds to save the day, how that turns out is down to you and your fast thinking. But it’s still fun none the less and the level comes back around faster than you can even think about it. It has a somewhat crude but hilarious sense of humour, with very bizarre gags in each stage.

The music is extremely repetitive, but strangely enough it isn’t annoying. It’s more catchy then annoying.
The main game is pretty short and there is a load of free DLC for you to play afterwards if you want to. (So there are a lot of days to save!)
If you were to play this nonstop the whole thing would probably take you a few hours, and it’s probably a good idea to take breaks due to its fast paced nature.

Generally I really enjoyed it; I thought it was pretty fun; there are a lot of references and things to have a laugh at in this game. So it’s something fun to throw on when you are bored.

reviewText:
What happens when you combine MacGyver, point and click, and fast paced insane logic? Well, you get McPixel, a game that isn’t afraid to throw logic out the window and give some straightforward jokes.

McPixel is a game that can be described as “WarioWare meets point and click adventure”. Each scene has a 20 second timer, with McPixel trying to save the day, often by disarming a bomb. Actions range from moving, picking up objects, and interacting with objects. Given the short time limit to solve the situation, players will tend to combine as many objects as possible. The game’s crazy logic behind the puzzles don’t tend to make sense and often the solutions are found by trial and error, though there are some more sane solutions that can be found. Solving each scene is simple, but the gameplay assists in something bigger, which is the game content itself.

In this game, McPixel must save the day. How he does so depends on the scene and the criteria for doing so is often stretched. Throughout the game, various gags are presented, often with random and crazy ideas. Often some gross out humor is applied, so be aware of the random jokes and occasional bodily functions. Along with these kinds of gags, many pop culture references are in the game, especially with TV and video games. These references I feel tend to work better at giving a good laugh, though the various random occurrences that don’t reference anything also are worth a laugh. Anyway, the bulk of the game is in its humor, and McPixel has no shortage of comedy to toss around and make you laugh.

On a short note, the game applies a retro style with its art and music. The game is pixelated like an old game, though McPixel does employ a consistent and certain character style. Scenery tends to be pixel art as well, or in some cases pixelated versions of photographs. Animations are crucial to delivering the game’s gags, and the crazy qualities of them work fine with the retro style. Music is the same way as well, using some chiptunes for some nice fat beats. There are not many songs and the tracks are quite short, but it does achieve the retro style with some neat chiptunes.

McPixel is a game for those looking to laugh at the absurd and crazy situations and interactions. Gameplay is kept simple to focus on delivering comedy, though the game’s crazy logic can make some puzzles confusing and require trial and error. Still, with some retro styling with the art and music mimicking old video games, McPixel makes for a game to laugh at some silly things.

Short version: 77%An absurd and sometimes obscene puzzle game that focuses on short visual gags and the most illogical solutions one can find to a problem. The strangest thing is that it works quite well either as a good bad game or just as a clever indie puzzle– with an excellent length/price ratio thanks to the continuous release of free new levels.

Long version:McPixel is the kind of game that you can hardly place anywhere. On one hand it’s obviously a joke title, full of obscene and sometimes downright retarded gags, completely illogical puzzles and an utterly insane basic idea: you have to defuse bombs at unusual places (including a lot of video game or movie themed levels) using the most absurd ways.

Still, despite the complete absence of logic, it works surprisingly well as a puzzle game, and the incentives to find all possible solutions can open up a few clever visual gags that really show how great imagination the creator has. It may not be a new Portal in terms of advancing puzzle games to the next level, but it offers a quick fun, and thanks to the many levels– including the free DLCs and community-created ones– it can last quite long, if you choose to stick with it.

reviewText:
In my 17 years of gaming, never have I come across a game that is so bad. It is basically a point and click game. The aim of the game is to locate and destroy/get rid of a bomb by clicking on objects on the screen. There are several stages which each has several levels.

The good points are that you get lots of levels (100) which you can happily sink alot of time in.


Now for the bad points. First off, although the game tries to be humorous by having you embarass or do terrible things to the characters in the game, some of the actions that the main character does may be offend/disturb people (e.g. peeing on an alien). Second is that when you start the game there is literally no tutorial which was somewhat frustrating trying to figure out what to do. Third issue is that when you fail to locate the bomb, you will proceed to the next level. The game then goes through all five levels of the stage untill you have disarmed the bomb in each stage. This forces you to remember exactly which items not to click on, but the main problem is that it is somewhat difficult to find which items can be interacted with. Fourth issue is that the game is extremely repetitive. Once you finished the first level, all the other levels are exactly the same except with new scenery. Fifth issue is that the music is really annoying as it plays 1 track for the ENTIRE game.

If you like point and click games, avoid this game. If you like a fun and enjoyable games, avoid this game. It isn't even worth $1 let alone $5.

McPixel

It's a weird mix of Wario Ware meets a 2D point & click (there's an interaction puzzle to solve on each one) & a weird nasty Flash pixelly game.

All with a heavy dose of Jackass humour.

reviewText:
McPixel is hard to review, but here's my attempt:

McPixel is a point and click adventure, in which you are thrust into a random world and forced to defuse some random situation in less than 3 seconds.  If you make the wrong choice, you fail that scenario.  But don't worry, you will fail many scenarios, as the correct path is hardly ever the most obvious.  And that's the charm of the game.  You essentially try these situations over and over, and you'll finally realize that you aren't supposed to pick up the dynamite you're supposed to kick the guy in his genitals (duh!)

This game reeks of potty humor, and slapstick comedy, and I find it hilarious!

reviewText:
McPixel is a point and click game adventure game.  Although enjoying very few point-and-click games, I was willing to give a chance to.  In the end, I did not find myself having a fun experience.

The game is meant to be a comedy of sorts, having both slapstick and crass humor.  Although some of the gags are good, the logic behind solving the puzzles is convoluted and confusing, sometimes having no logic at all.  This results in you usually having to just use trial and error over and over to figure out the right order of operations to solve a level.  This is made somewhat less annoying, however, as the load times between failed attempts is very quick.  In my opinion, the gameplay would better fit a more narrative driven game than a rapid-paced puzzle game.

The other problem I had with the game was the music.  Throughout the entire game, only one very repetitive music track is used.  At least as far as I got, there is no sound effects, ambient noises, voice acting, etc.  This means the one looping music track is the only thing you will hear throughout the entire session.

Although I did not find the game fun, players who enjoy rage games" would probably get a few good laughs out of the game.  I would recommend waiting for a sale however

reviewText:
An insta-fail, counterintuitive, yet enjoyable pixelated point-and-click game. The task is simple: keep the bomb from exploding in various sets of maps and situations.
There's not much more about it: every map contains a few characters and environmental elements (some hidden ones too) and you have a few clicks to get the right ones in the right order so your ethically-questionable hero McPixel can take action and throw the bomb away, or shield it, or defuse it and so on.

The extremely simple gameplay is weirdly balanced by the major unpredictability of the solution, so you end up frenetically repeating the same set of maps (six every stage) over and over again until you finally get it done.
There's also a bonus stage unlocked every time you get a streak of three wins together, but that happens so rarely (unless you're replaying it) that it can be considered a rare event.

Of course it can be me: maybe there's actually a pattern by which you can solve all the maps without a doubt, but I couldn't last enough in the game to get it. One reason may be the fact that I couldn't bear gaming sessions longer than 5 or 10 minutes because of the confusion-to-rage inducing solutions and the constantly looping two seconds background 8-bit music (come on...)

It's difficult to me to imagine actually completing the entire game, so I can't really figure how one could possibly find the motivation to replay it afterwards.

To sum it up, for me it makes an ok game to play when you don't have much time (and something else to listen to), but nothing more.

Ingredients:
1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour
3 tablespoons sugar
1 tablespoon baking powder
1/4 teaspoon salt
1/8 teaspoon freshly ground nutmeg
2 large eggs, at room temperature
1 1/4 cups milk, at room temperature
1/2 teaspoon pure vanilla extract
3 tablespoons unsalted butter, plus more as needed

Now to make it
1. In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, baking powder, salt, and nutmeg.
2. In another bowl, beat the eggs and then whisk in the milk and vanilla.
3. Melt the butter in a large cast iron skillet or griddle over medium heat.
4. Whisk the butter into the milk mixture. Add the wet ingredients to the flour mixture, and whisk until a thick batter is just formed
5. Keeping the skillet at medium heat, ladle about 1/4 cup of the batter onto the skillet, to make a pancake. Make 1 or 2 more pancakes, taking care to keep them evenly spaced apart. Cook, until bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, and the undersides are golden brown, about 2 minutes. Flip with a spatula and cook about 1 minute more on the second side. Serve immediately or transfer to a platter and cover loosely with foil to keep warm. Repeat with the remaining batter, adding more butter to the skillet as needed.
6. Procedure for adding fruit to pancakes: Once the bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, scatter the surface with sliced or diced fruit, or chocolate chips, nuts, etc. Flip with a spatula and cook for 1 minute more, being careful not to burn toppings.

reviewText: There is always some level of arbitrariness in a point & click.  Logically there might be a dozen ways to make a guard leave his post or to interact with a pump, but only one will be correct because of the artificial nature of the game.  A good point and click will keep this under control with reasonable puzzle solutions, while rewarding the player for their time and effort with humor, good music, an interesting story or other unique charm.  McPixel does none of this.  The music is short, repetitive, and not at all pleasing to listen to.  The puzzle solutions are arbitrary enough that all you can really do is click whatever is in the level until you manage to click the correct objects in the correct order.  It lacks a cohesive narrative.  There is humor, but it is crass and juvenile; even compared to other crass, juvenile humor, McPixel is in the back of the pack.\n\nThere is no reason to buy this game at any price.  There will always be something better to spend your money on.

reviewText:
Be forewarned, I am only through the first level of this game, but I am already hooked. This game is gloriously stupid, patently ridiculous, an absolutely hilarious. It's good enough to need three adverbs.

You play as McPixel, I think, who is a MacGuyver/MacGruber type protagonist who only has thirty seconds to stop things from exploding. The gameplay is very simple point and click adventure style, the graphics are old school pixel art, and the music is something you expect from an Atari 2600 title, but all of it works perfectly together.

The puzzles are simple, yet clever. It's worth getting them wrong just for the hilarity of the consequences. I've been slapped by Buddah, had a cow fall in love with me, fed a hot dog to a pot-smoking alien, and made a man poop dynamite in the span of five minutes.

This game is absolutely worth $1.99. I haven't played long enough to know if it's worth the full price, but considering I've already laughed more at this than I would at most modern comedy movies in a theater, I'm going to tentatively say that yes.
